document.text: year plan with each faculty and  asked members to submit recommendations The superin tendent compiled recommen dations and submitted the list to council members. At an October meeting recommendations were review ed and the main objectives to beincluded inathe plan were agreed upon. A tentative document includ ing objectives and. strategies was reviewed by the Central Planning Council on December 1. The school board received a revised draft of the plan on 4ecember 11 it,was .reviewed  and changes as determined necessary were, made and the document was approved at the regular January 1981 hoard meeting, Council will continue -to meet  on a regular schedule to review progress of the school system toward achievement of. objec tives. The Appomattox County School Board - and, school personnel are not only interest ed in providing the best in education to youth of this county, they are interested in what happens following grad uation. So interested, in fact, they conduct à follow-up study to determine the status of students who graduated at the end of the previous year. M., will re ceive bids for a school bus to run from a point one mile be yond the present Bent Creek white schoolhouse, on Rt. 13, by Bent Creek to Oakville, on Route 306. document.text: will help the schools prevent problems in this area. Behavior and Conduct It is the firm belief of the Appomattox County School Board and school officials that a structured and orderly environ ment is necessary for a successful school system. We believe that parents share this same belief with us. Reasonable rules and regula tions are a part of every successful institution. The school system is no exception. The School Board has basic policies which are necessary for the operation of the school system in an effective and efficient manner. School offi cials will make every effort to enforce these policies. J There are reasonable stand ards of behavior and conduct which are established for students, while under the supervision of the schools. This covers the regular daily program from the time the student boards the school bus in the morning until he gets off the bus in the afternoon. All other school sponsored activi ties are included. The schools will make every effort to help students understand what is expected of them and to provide an environment con ducive to acceptable conduct and behavior. The schools will also work closely with parents regarding areas of concern and seek your help in correcting problems. School Evaluations Under the direction of the School Board, school employees follow a continuous plan to

document.text: were furnished prior to admission to another school or school division, and provide the information contained in the physical report and certificate. Children may attend kinder garten during the 1981-82 school year who have reached their fifth birthday on or before Dec. 91 of the school year. A parent or guardian enrolling a child who will reach the age of five after Sept. 30 and on or before Dec. 31 of the school year in a kindergarten program will want to discuss with the principal the advisa- bility of the child attending kindergarten.- Children may be admitted to first grade for the 1961-82 school session who have reached their sixth birthday on or before Dec. 31, 1961. To verify a childs age, parents must present a birth certificate, hospital statement or acceptable record upon registration at their local school. Employment of personnel and development of plans for the 1981-82 school year are based on the enrollment of school students. Therefore, it is very important that all children who are eligible to enter kindergarten or first grade next year who are not in school this year register on March 25 or .26. The Appomattox County School Board appreciates the publics cooperation.

ABBITT, p.q. 7-81-4t APPOMATTOX COUNTY SCHOOLS Notice to Parents or Guardians of Handicapped Children The Special Education Pro gram of the Appom attox County School System is operated according to Federal and State Guidelines. These guidelines require par ental permission 1. to place a student in a program of special education, 2. to continue the student in a special education program, and,  3. to change the program. These guidelines also give parents of handicapped chil dren the right 1. to request special education placement or evaluation for such placement, 2. to reje ct eith er special education placement or special evaluation, and, 3  to request reports of .todies obtained for or used -.in consideration of special educa tion placement. document.text: TO WHOM IT MAY CON CERN Please take notice that the Appomattox County School Board will sit in regular meet ing at the Courthouse, Appo mattox Va., beginning prompt ly at 1000 A. M., Wednesday, July 9, to receive bids and pro posals for school truck routes for the .session 1930-31. All parties interested, either as pa trons or as applicants and bid ders for truck routes, are in vited to appear. All bids Or proposals for truck routes must be in writing and sealed and presented to the Board on that day or before then to the office of the Division Superintendent, Appomattox, Va. It is specifi cally understood that the Board reserves the right to re ject any or all bids. In pre senting the bids, please state definitely what route you are applying for. Please observe the following general specifi cations  1. It is the intention of the Board that for next session as far as possible, to discontinue the use of canvas covered bod ies and therefore in every case where the roads will permit, regular bus bodies will be re quired or at least home made bodies of the better type. Qn the following routes the regu lar bodies will be required Stonewall to Appomattox j Vera to Appomattox Ever green to Appomattox Oakville to Appomattox and Reedy Spring to Appomattox. 2. Drivers cabs separated from the regular seating part of the truck will not.be accep ted. The pupils and the driver must all be located in the same compartment. Contractors will be required to i inspect their trucks carefully each day and wW have to maintain their truck bodies in the. same con dition throughout the session as at the beginning. 3. In presenting bids, state who the driver will be and this with the understanding that no substituting will be allowed Without permission. All previous regulations not mentioned herein are in full force and effect. Very truly yours, J. A. BURKE, Superintendent -------------- o ----------  CIRCUIT COURT

document.text: To date, over 250 families have used the facilities of the school cannery in conserving food. A to tal of 47 individuals have been enrolled so far. Vegetables have been the most popular item to date, with the records showing 32,806 cans packed 16,083 of fnflt, ffnd 1,374 cans of meat. During the rest of the season, it is expected that the total volume of meat can ned will increase at a rapid rate. Pupils of the late Miss Kate FrankUn, focal music teacher. Massed in the spring production. One day when browsing among hr souvenirs, Mrs. Jean Hesson of dhe Appomattox County School Board  office, and a member of the production, found an old program listing those participating in the recital. Although she was in the production, Jean Hesson doesnt remember the yeir and it wasnt listed on the program. It seems that none ef us who had a part in this production can remember the yew, or do you suppose w just dont want to? The theme of the musical went something like this... Marion, Jean Akers Hesson, was a  student who was lamenting over scale practice Her mother, played by Katherine Burge Weatherly, very carefully explained how important it was to learn how to play the scales well. She managed to get her point across with the help of figures from the part- a Taking the parts of figures from the past were Thelma. Covington, Mary Owen Carson, Agnes Jennings, Lorraine . Hamilton Torrence, Ruth Hesson and Dorothy. document.text: thus permit larger use by the workign public. Through its interest the members of the Friends of the Library have drawn up a list of priority needs to improve the Library established in 1940, but now greatly in need of updating to meet the needs of a community which has begun to grow and expand with the arrival in our area of the Armstrong Furniture Company and other businesses. Books need to be purchased, research materials added, and out of date materials need to be replaced. A Citizens Advisory Board to the Appomattox County School Board recommends various needed improvements and repairs such as a fire escape from the second floor childrens department, painting walls, air conditioning, renovation of rooms and stacks, but the enthusiastic support of the Friends can bring about such improvements as replacing outdated and dilapidated refer ence works.

document.text: The University of Virginia has scheduled an extension class in Appomattox for the fall term. The class number and title is EDCI589 Teaching Techniques New Ideas and Methods, -Three hours of graduate or undergraduate credits will be given for successful completion of the class. The class will begin on September 6, at 700 p.m. in Room 228 at Appomattox County High School. The Appomattox County School Board arranges with the University of Virginia School of Continuing Education for classes to be offered in the tall and spring semesters and for a June three weeks session to be conducted. These classes are planned for instructional personnel who are renewing teaching certifi cates, seeking additional endorse ments or gaining more depth in their respective areas of assign ment. The classes are also open to persons who are not employed by the school system. The tuition cost is 150.00 for persons who do not hold a contract in Appomattox County. Additional information may be secured by calling Mrs. Jean Hesson at the School Board Office. The telephone number is 352-8251.

document.text: The graduating class of 1964 held its 8 year reunion Saturday Aug. 29th, at W. W. Burkes Lake. The members began ar riving at 2 p.m. and all enjoyed the fellowship of past class mates. Dinner was catered by P a r k w a y Restaurant. Coach Gordon Bragg was the only fa culty member attending. Watkins Abbitt, acting presi dent, called a business meeting to order and Merlyn Carroll was elected new corresponding secretary in the absence of the past secretary. The class un animously voted to send a letter to the Appomattox County School Board proposing that the new high school be named Earl J. Smith High School in honor of

document.text: The Drug Education Com mittee of the Appomattox County School Board met in the Appomattox County High School on Mon., Dec. 20. President, Roland Murphy, called the meeting to order and asked that the minutes of the previous meeting be read. The purposes of this commit tee are to keep abreast of problems related to the abuse of drugs, to bring together, the different community agencies to assist the school system in its .educational program, to assist in the enforcement of School Board policies withregard to drugs and to help communicate to the community positive developments, as well as problems. _ _ Areas discussed in the meeting on Monday included programs and activities plan ned for the schools during the 1976-77 session, assistance of other agencies and identifica tion of additional needs. Dr. A. A. Fratrick, School Board Chairman and member of the committee, stated that the Appomattox County School Board favored effective and appropriate instruction in all grades to help students practice good health habits, self-discipline and responsible citizenship. Our first priority

document.text: The dedication to the process of learning as long as one lives is a noble attribute. Mr. Percy Johnson has shown that he believes this. Mr. Johnson has attended the Adult Basic Education classes sponsored by the Appomattox County School Board. A recent Monday class was a red letter night for Mr. Johnson. He had often seen his wife working crossword puz zles. On this night the mysteries of working these puzzles were opened to him. His elation was wonderful to see. A new element of living was his to use. A Monday or two before the mysteries of the dictionary became a functional reality to him. Mr. Johnson has been very inquisitive from the beginning of his joining the class . On this night he asked the teacher, Mrs. Ramsey, and the aide, Mrs. Torrence, why certain words at the bottom of their newspaper were written as they were. He was told they were written that way to help in the use of the dictionary. He was also shown how it helped to pronounce the word. The next Monday night he brought his own dictionary and was off to a new dimension in learning. Mr. Johnson, during the day

document.text: the board voted to lower county real estate ate by 10 cents per 100 value and signed application and resolut ions necessary to begin construction on the new county high school. At the May meeting of the Appomattox County School Board, resolution was signed naming J. E. Jamerson  Sons Contractors for the new school and set May 15. 1972, as the starting date with construction scheduled to be completed by July of 1974. J. E. Jamerson  Sons oi Appomattox had submitted the low bid on the new Appomattox County High School with a base bid of 3,154,674. At the end of last year, things were beginning to take on shape at the school site and work was pretty well on schedule. Frank C. Chuchek, Principal at Appomattox County High School was appointed General Supervisor of county schools and H. Wayne Tucker, Princi pal at Essex High School, Tappahannock, Virginia, was appointed to succeed Chuchek effective July 1st. In 1972, Appomattox County High School awarded 161 diplomas at the commencement exercises on June 9th. 150 students enrolled for summer school under the Title I program. Citizens of our county were . uddiMv.to learn of the cath of Earl J. Smith on July 11, 1972. Mr. Smith, having served as Superintendent of Appo mattox County Schools for 10 years, died suddenly in Grand Rapids, Michigan, while on a business trip for the school system. On August 11, 1972, at the regular meeting of the Appo mattox County School Board, Eugene W. Peyton was appointed Superintendent of Schools for Appomattox Coun ty. He had been a c t i n g superintendent since the death of Earl J. Smith. In other changes of person nel in the school system, Frank C. Chuchek was elevated to the position of Administrative Assistant Mrs. Jean Hesson was appointed General Super visor and W. Thomas Johnson was named Principal of Appo mattox Elementary School. Appomattox County High School had a good record in the sports scene last year, too. The Raiders Varsity Basket ball team ended their regular season with a 14-4 overall record and a 10-4 district re cord. They were runners-up in the Seminole District and advanced to semi-finals of the Regional III, AA tournament and went on to the finals but lost out in the Championship round. The Raiderettes were 11-3 for the season in the Seminole District with a 12-3 overall re cord. The Raiderettes lost to Rustburg by 3 points in the opening game of the district semi-finals but really had a good season anyway. On the baseball field the Raiders won the Seminole Dis trict Tourney but lost out in the Regional Championship by the narrowest of scores, 4 to 3, losing to Tunstall. The Raiderettes Volleyball team, undefeated for the season, won the Championship trophy for the district in tournament play. During the 1972 football season, the Raiders ended the season with a 7-3 overall re cord, and a 6-2 record in the Seminole District. The Raiders placed six players on All-Dis trict first team and put three players on the All-District second team. In the Spring of 1972 Harry G. Lawson, Commonwealth

document.text: The Board of Supervisors, meeting in regular session cm Friday morning in the Clerks office, approved a resolution presented by the Appomattox County School Board requesting the supervisors to issue 2 mil lion in bonds to be sold to the Va. Public School authority. The supervisors, in effect, gave approval to the securing of funds for a high school to be located on land purchased sev eral years ago adjacent to Road 727 south of the town of Appo mattox. Approval to build the school was given by the super visors on February 9, 1968. The approved resolution pro vides a way by which a locality may borrow money at a rate cheaper than funds can be ob tained on the open market. The School Board drew up the resolution in a called meet ing on Thursday evening, Dec. 9. According to Supt. Earl J. Smith, the action by the super visors will also mean that Ap pomattox is eligible to obtain 500,000 in vocational funds to assist in the construction of a vocational-agriculture b u il d - ing. He said, further,  Wehave been assured that funds will be available for a school here if commitments are made to begin construction by July of 1972. Plans for the new school are complete and have been approv ed by the State Board of Educa tion. AiYti.xiai funds for the school, estimated to cost about 3 million, will be obtained through a Literary Fund loan of 500,000, also a low-interest 3 source of funds for school construction. Supervisor John C. Cole ask ed the Supt. if the costs of the school are definitely set .  We do not want to put our selves in the position of an escalating situation, Cole said. Supt. Smith said that he feels that the figures given for con struction are sound ones. The Supt. thanked the board for its action and added, 1 have enough faith in Appomattox county to feel that this new school will lead to a better community. Welfare Dept. Supervisors also announced the appointment of Mrs. B. G. Anderson EUa to the Appomat tox County Welfare Board. Mrs. Anderson, retired home dem onstration agent in Appomattox and home management specia list, University of Kentucky for several years prior to her re turn to Appomattox, replaced Mr. Herbert C. Pulliam, owner and manager of Pulliam Motor Sales, Appomattox. Mr. Pul liams residence is now inClo- verhill D i s t r i c t rather than Southside which he formerly re presented. This is a result of the recent redistricting which has brought about other changes in appointive positions in the coun ty. I Other members of the Wel fare Board include a supervisor representative, O.H. Tolly, Jr. of Pamplin and Clayton Martin, landowner and farmer. Contd on Page 6C

document.text: The Appomattox County School Board wiU meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Thursday, May 13 at 7 p.m. Items on. the agenda are as follows consideration of School Board Policy related to special education review and discus sion of School Board Policy related to educational leave for twelve months employees report on drug education phase of the curriculum in kindergarten through grade 12 accreditation of Appomattox County Schools by the State Department of Education report on progress of plans relative to implementation of Title IX  consideration of School Division calendar for 1976-77 report on the imple mentation of a hearing impair ed program for 1976-77 proposal for ail Individualized System Approach to teaching Automotive Engine Repair consideration of Title I Advis ory Committee for 1976-77 and the Superintendents Report.

Ge neral Education Development or High School Equivalency classes will be held at Appom attox Intermediate School. Basic Education for Adults will be sponsored at Pamplln Elementary and Appomattox County High School. These classes In Basic Eduaction will be for adults who have an eighth grade or less education. Information con c e r n i n g all classes will be available by August 28 and may be secured by calling the School Board Office, telephone 352-8253 or writing the Home School Coor dinator.

The Appomattox County School Board will offer to area adults two classes in their Gen eral Adult Education Program beginning January 24, 1972. Shorthand I will be offered if at least 10 adults enroll. Typing I will be offered if at least 15 adults enroll. A maximum of 25 adults will be enrolled, in the typing class. For further information call Daniel W. Davis, Home-School Coordinator, Telephone 352-82 53 or write him at the Appomat tox County School Board office.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet Wednesday March 16 at 330 p.m. in the school board office on Main Street, Appomattox. Heading the list of agenda items is consideration of the school division budget for the 1983-84 session. The board will also consider revising the school division calendar for the current year, and discuss the division calendar for the 1983-84 session.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room on Main Street on Wednesday, May 10th, 1978, at 3p.m. Items on the agenda will include review of revised school board policies, review of retirement program for classifi ed employees, review of report from AMS Visiting Committee review of School Board Insurance policies, review of report from Title IV-C Evalua tion Committee, review of students . fees for 1978-79 session, and financial report.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Wednesday, June 7, 1978 at 3 p.m . Items on the agenda will include adoption of school board policies, review and discussion of Appomattox County Educa tion Association Program of Action, review and discussion of Annual and Six-Year Division Plans, approval of student fees for 1978-79 session, review and approval of school board liability and property insurance for 1978 fiscal year, and a financial report.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Wednesday, December 6,1978, at 300 p.m. Items on the agenda will include review of social studies competencies recommended for Appomattox County students review of factors influencing the 1979-80 school board budget consideration of re vised special education policies report on Title IV-C Career Guidance Project attendance report for November and financial report. Board members will meet for lunch and visit in several schools prior to the regular meeting at 300 p.m. They will meet at the School Board Office at 1200 noon and go to one of the schools for lunch.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Tuesday, November 7,1978, at 7 p.m. Items on the agenda will include discussion of six-year plans in Vocational Education, Special Education, and School Division report on drug education forum held on October 17 and plans for other activities in the schools on drug education review of Title I activities review of proposed guidelines for assessing student conduct and attendance and attendance report for October.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Thurs., Sept. 2 at 3 p.m. Items on the agenda will include approval of resolution governing the use and loan of a 1977 Chevrolet to be used in driver training program accep tance of an Indian Artifact display for the County Library from Dr. Clyde OBrien report from the superintendent on pre-school conference, enroll ment, and finances adult report of the 1975-76 session report on drug education committee meeting report on program plans as related to Southern Association of Col leges and Schools and consi deration of ideas to maintain effective communication within the system and with the community.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Monday, August 2, 1976 at 7 p.m. Items on the agenda will include report on Title IX evaluation, committee to study the report cards used in the system, drug education com mittee, teacher aide handbook and evaluation guide, substi tute teacher handbook, Alloca tion of departm ent funds, report on summer conference held in Charlottesville, and review of ACHS Scholarship Fund.

Prior to the meeting at 3 p.m ., the board members will eat lunch in one of the schools and observe the school pro gram.

Review of proposed resolution for con sideration by the legislative committee of Virginia School Boards Association and 3. consideration of tuition assis tance for handicapped students

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room at the School Board Office on Main Street on Thursday night, October 9 at 7 p.m. Items on the agenda will include the following 1. appointment of Special Educa tion Committee 2. view of 1975-76 budget and the reduction in State funds of 5 8. general report on programs and development relative to the 1975-76 session 4. considera tion of reviewed School Board policy regarding student disci pline and 5. report on Virginia School Boards Association annual meeting.

The Appomattox County School Board will meet in regular session in the Board Room at the School Board Office on Friday, Sept. 12, at 3 p.m. Items on the agenda will include the following 1 . report on the 1975-76 school session 2. adoption of policy regarding management of the students scholastic records 3. adoption of policy regarding the determi nation of the eligibility of students for Special Education Classes 4. adoption of the Athletic Program for 1975-76 5. approval of a work-study program for 1975-76 and 6 . selection of School Board delégate to attend a meeting of the Virginia School Boards Association Oct. 2-4,1975 at the Hqtel John Marshall in Rich mond.

document.text: The Appomattox County School Board will m eet in regular session in the Board Room in Appomattox on Friday, September 8, 1978, at 3 p.m. A Item i on the agenda will in clude a report from a represen tative of the County Library Advisory Committee report on Appomattox County Forum on Drug Education scheduled at Appomattox County High School on September 18, at 730 p.m . report on student enrollm ent for the 1978-79 session report from Mrs. Dorothy Oliver and Mrs. Jean Mills on health promotion and prevention program in which these two sixth grade teachers participated this sum m er report oh bids received on leasepurchase of a 34 passenger school bus with UR attachm ent for handicapped children review of im provements made in school facilities during the summer review of Mscipline procedures which schools will follow during the 1976-79 session and con sideration of tuition assistance for special education students.

The Appomattox County School Board will hold its monthly meeting Tuesday, Nov. 12 at 3 p.m. in the board room at the School Board Office. The Tuesday meeting is a departure from the regular meetings, usually held the second Thursday of each month. Several items are on the agenda including report on the Reading Program, a report on the In Service Program, which will be held Nov. 7 in Lynchburg, a progress report on the Vocational Education programs and a report on the Special Education Program. Also the board will appoint a Central Planning Council for the school system for the 1974-75 school year and will hear a proposal from Miss Sue Holland of the Central Virginia Mental Health Service. Miss Holland has asked that, the county schools participate in a program called Students Organized for Developing Attitudes SODA, a drug prevention program which utilizes high school students in an advisory capacity.

The Appomattox County School Board will accept sealed bids on the following vehicles 2 1960 Chevrolet, 54 passen ger buses Bids may be submitted to the Appomattox County School Board or the School Bus Shop, Appomattox, Virginia, on or before 400 p.m., Wednesday, November 24, 1976, at which time the bids will be opened in thé School Bus Shop. These buses may be seen at the Appomattox County School Bus Shop on Route 460 in the town of Appomattox. Sales transactions will be on a cash basis only. The School Board reserves the right to reject any and all bids. Authorized by Appomattox County School Board. Lloyd G. Walton Division Superintendent ll-4-3t
